awd_titl_txt: CREST Center for Cellular and Biomolecular Machines
awd_abstract_narration:
Center for Cellular and Biomolecular Machines  

With National Science Foundation support, the University of California Merced will establish the Center for Cellular and Biomolecular Machines. The Center will use an interdisciplinary approach cutting across scientific and engineering methodologies to (i) pursue a fundamental understanding of the structure, dynamics and functioning of multi-scale biomolecular and cellular assemblies; (ii) use these fundamental principles for designing and developing novel bio-inspired functioning machines ranging from designer cells and tissue to diagnostic and therapeutic devices; and (iii) develop an integrated, interdisciplinary training program for graduate students that will combine physical and biological components with supervision of research and training experiences for undergraduate students and high school teachers. 

Center research is organized around three subprojects based on the scales of the assemblies and processes involved. Subproject 1, entitled Biomolecular Machines, investigates circadian molecular clocks to develop sensors capable of monitoring specific biological processes inside cells in real time. Center researchers will investigate the molecular mechanisms of the cyanobacterial oscillator that is composed of three monomeric proteins that autonomously maintains time in vitro. Researchers will also develop proofs of concept for single-molecule biosensors and apply them to investigate the cellular events that occur during cardiac dysfunction in an in vivo model. 

Entitled Macromolecular Assemblies and Hybrid Devices, subproject 2 will study material properties of innovative assemblies of biomolecules, inorganic matter and/or their mixtures to produce enhanced functionality and devices. This method will be applied to develop a sensor for Valley Fever that is caused by a fungal infection.  

Subproject 3, entitled Cellular and Multicellular Systems, investigates large scale assemblies composed of multiple cells. Center research focuses on bacterial community motility and stem cell differentiation. Emphasis will be placed on the effect of mechanical force on cell fate. 

Progress in these areas may lead to therapeutic improvements in human health and the implementation of design principles for building bio-inspired materials and machines.

por.por_cntn:
The mission for the Center for Cellular and Biomolecular Machines (CCBM) was to establish the fundamental infrastructure at the University of California Merced for investigating the structure and operational principles of multi-scale biological systems. This mission was formulated via the implementation of synergistic research and educational objectives: i) advance the fundamental understanding of the structure, dynamics and functioning of multiscale biomolecular and cellular assemblies; (ii) apply these principles for the design and development of novel bio-inspired functioning machines; and iii) develop an integrated, interdisciplinary training program for graduate students combined with research and training experiences for undergraduate students aimed at enhancing and developing career opportunities for underrepresented minorities in STEM fields.

CCBM research on understanding how hierarchical assemblies of molecular, cellular, and multicellular structures self-organize and perform sophisticated functions and developing design principles for new adaptive materials and devices involved 30 faculty members from six different departments at UC Merced. These research efforts were organized in three thrusts, defined according to hierarchical scale: T1- biomolecular instruments and machines; T2- macromolecular assemblies and hybrid devices; T3- cellular and multicellular systems. Over the last 6.5 years CCBM researchers vigorously advanced our general understanding of the organization, operation, and control of biological and bioinspired systems at the three scales, resulting on multiple important outcomes.  

Thrust 1 focused on protein nanomachines and instruments, including studies of the circadian clock and the mechanisms of gene expression and inflammation, and the design and engineering of protein biosensors for real-time monitoring in living cells. Some key basic research outcomes include the elucidation of the high-resolution structures of essential components of the circadian clock and the inflammasome, the discovery of promiscuous DNA recognition as mechanism for efficient tracking of target genes in eukaryotes, and methods to investigate how the cellular environment regulates biological function of intrinsically disordered proteins. Important applied science and engineering outcomes include the demonstration of how to engineer de novo allosteric control of protein assembly; development of design principles for implementing fluorescence biosensors based on folding coupled to binding, and optimizing their time response and dynamic range; and the demonstration of biomimetic cell-like containers able to autonomously keep time.  

Thrust 2 focused on hybrid and active systems, leading to several major advances. One exciting area was the development of novel microshell delivery systems that can be activated with infrared or electrical stimulation for spatio-temporarily controlled delivery of payload to tissues. Another outcome was an improved understanding of the basic dynamics of topological defects and entropy production in active bioinspired materials consisting of cytoskeletal filaments and molecular motors, with hold the promise of enabling their control and utilization. Thrust 2 researchers also uncovered new ways in which teamwork between molecular motors is promoted by the use of cargo surface fluidity, with implications for transport processes that occur in vivo.

Thrust 3 efforts targeted the assembly and movement of multicellular structures. Significant outcomes include the development of de novo vasculature with unprecedented stability from mixtures of mural cells within microfluidic devices, which constitutes a vital step toward perfusable organoid growth in vitro. Thrust 3 researchers made major strides in understanding the mechanics of collective migration of malignant cancer cell clusters; and in the elucidation of how substrate mediated mechanical interactions guide the dynamics and self-assembly of cells such as it occurs in endothelial vascular networks. Major advances were also made in understanding the collective behavior of small groups of bacteria and bacterial biofilm dynamics.

CCBM provided general support to the UC Merced research enterprise by establishing and running mass spectrometry, computational, and biophysical instrumentation facilities, as well as by training researchers and students in their use. CCBM played a pivotal role in developing programs for graduate and undergraduate students, and led a variety of outreach efforts to the California Central Valley, a historically socially and economically disadvantaged region with a large minority population. From 2016-2022 CCBM provided fellowships to 38 graduate students. Twenty-three of those students were either women, Latino/Hispanic, Black/African American and/or American Indian. Twelve funded students completed their Ph.D. degrees, including five females, and one Latino/Hispanic and one Black/African American. In addition, CCBM impacted over 260 graduate students through programming including scientific seminars, workshops, conferences, summer modules, training sessions, and courses. CCBM funded 152 undergraduates in research experiences including 101 during the academic years, and 51 Summer Internship Program participants of which 15 came from UC Merced and 36 from other universities from across California and the U.S. More than 500 undergraduate students were impacted by CCBM organized undergraduate programs. Of the 190 graduate and undergraduate students funded, 95 were women, 56 were Latino/Hispanic, and 10 were Black/African American. Of the women supported, 33 were Latino/Hispanic and five were Black/African American. Additionally, the Center led engaging STEM outreach programming leading to over 2,000 diverse student, teacher, and community experiences.
